elements.content: High-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction reaction are extremely desirable to produce valuable hydrocarbon productions, as well as addressing the current environmental challenges. In this work, we introduce a Cu-based metal–organic framework as a catalyst for the efficient and selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 in neutral aqueous electrolytes. Detailed examination of [Cu 4 ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Cu 4 -MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis­(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4′,5′-i])­dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin) revealed the highest activity for yielding methane with a Faradaic efficiency of 92%/88% and a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm–2 at a potential of −1.2/–1.3 V (vs RHE). In situ X-ray absorption and infrared spectroscopy spectra, as well as density functional theory calculations, revealed that the in situ generated trigonal pyramidal Cu­(I)­N3 acts as the electrochemical active site and that the strong coordination ability of the Cu­(I)­N3 site and the synergistic effect of adjacent aromatic hydrogen atoms, via hydrogen-bonding interactions, play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of carbon dioxide reduction and inhibiting the hydrogen evolution reaction, thus showing a high performance of electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.
elements.clean_text: High-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction reaction are extremely desirable to produce valuable hydrocarbon productions, as well as addressing the current environmental challenges. In this work, we introduce a Cu-based metal-organic framework as a catalyst for the efficient and selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 in neutral aqueous electrolytes. Detailed examination of [Cu 4 ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Cu  4  -MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4',5'-i])dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin) revealed the highest activity for yielding methane with a Faradaic efficiency of 92%/88% and a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm-2 at a potential of -1.2/-1.3 V (vs RHE). In situ X-ray absorption and infrared spectroscopy spectra, as well as density functional theory calculations, revealed that the in situ generated trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 acts as the electrochemical active site and that the strong coordination ability of the Cu(I)N3 site and the synergistic effect of adjacent aromatic hydrogen atoms, via hydrogen-bonding interactions, play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of carbon dioxide reduction and inhibiting the hydrogen evolution reaction, thus showing a high performance of electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.

elements.content: Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) powered by renewable energy sources is now attracting intensive attention due to its mild reaction conditions and various valuable products. As a series of excellent electrocatalysts for CO2RR, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibit high specific surface areas, distinctive channel structures, designable frameworks, and abundant active sites, which enable them to be suitable for electrocatalysis. Currently, almost all pristine MOFs tend to result in CO as the main product in electrochemical CO2RR. However, high value-added hydrocarbons (e.g., methane, ethane, and ethylene) are more desirable. Copper-based composites, consisting of Cu-based MOFs and conventional CO2RR catalysts such as Cu2O and Cu nanoparticles, could achieve electrochemical conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons. Nevertheless, these known composites show a limited efficiency for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). Moreover, these Cu­(II) ion-based active materials often exhibit structural decomposition during CO2 electroreduction coupled with the reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I), and the catalytic activities were mainly originated from the derived Cu cluster or Cu2O. Therefore, developing stable and highly active Cu-MOF and investigating their structure–activity relationship would be significant for further understanding pristine MOF-based electrocatalysts in highly selective CO2 conversion toward valuable hydrocarbon production.
elements.clean_text: Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) powered by renewable energy sources is now attracting intensive attention due to its mild reaction conditions and various valuable products. As a series of excellent electrocatalysts for CO2RR, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibit high specific surface areas, distinctive channel structures, designable frameworks, and abundant active sites, which enable them to be suitable for electrocatalysis. Currently, almost all pristine MOFs tend to result in CO as the main product in electrochemical CO2RR. However, high value-added hydrocarbons (e.g., methane, ethane, and ethylene) are more desirable. Copper-based composites, consisting of Cu-based MOFs and conventional CO2RR catalysts such as Cu2O and Cu nanoparticles, could achieve electrochemical conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons. Nevertheless, these known composites show a limited efficiency for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). Moreover, these Cu(II) ion-based active materials often exhibit structural decomposition during CO2 electroreduction coupled with the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I), and the catalytic activities were mainly originated from the derived Cu cluster or Cu2O. Therefore, developing stable and highly active Cu-MOF and investigating their structure-activity relationship would be significant for further understanding pristine MOF-based electrocatalysts in highly selective CO2 conversion toward valuable hydrocarbon production.

elements.content: Generally, electroreduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons usually involves a *CO intermidiate. If the binding strength of the catalyst and CO is weak or the intermediate subsequent to the *CO intermediate is unstable, CO will be the main reduction product; otherwise, hydrogenation of the *CO intermediate will be processed and hydrocarbons can be finally generated. Therefore, optimizing the binding strength of the catalyst and key intermediates should be a favorable method to obtain high performance for electroreduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons. Considering the high selectivity and activity of Cu ions for hydrocarbon reduction products and that the azolate derivatives have been demonstrated as suitable ligands for highly stable MOFs, porous metal–azolate frameworks possessing exposed Cu ions on the pore surface may act as the highly efficient and stable electrocatalysts for reduction of CO2 into hydrocarbons.
elements.clean_text: Generally, electroreduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons usually involves a *CO intermidiate. If the binding strength of the catalyst and CO is weak or the intermediate subsequent to the *CO intermediate is unstable, CO will be the main reduction product; otherwise, hydrogenation of the *CO intermediate will be processed and hydrocarbons can be finally generated. Therefore, optimizing the binding strength of the catalyst and key intermediates should be a favorable method to obtain high performance for electroreduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons. Considering the high selectivity and activity of Cu ions for hydrocarbon reduction products and that the azolate derivatives have been demonstrated as suitable ligands for highly stable MOFs, porous metal-azolate frameworks possessing exposed Cu ions on the pore surface may act as the highly efficient and stable electrocatalysts for reduction of CO2 into hydrocarbons.

elements.content: Previously, Volkmer et al. reported an azolate MOF, namely, [Zn5Cl4(btdd)3] (MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis­(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4′,5′-i])­dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin), constructed by the cationic pentanuclear {Zn5Cl4}6+ clusters and the btdd2– ligands, which has a large pore aperture of 9.13 Å (). There are two types of Zn­(II) ions in the {Zn5Cl4}6+ cluster, including four tetrahedral Zn­(II) ions, each being coordinated by three N atoms from btdd2– ligands at the base and one Cl– at the apex of the tetrahedron, and one octahedral Zn­(II) ion coordinated by six N atoms from six hexadentate btdd2– ligands. Partial Zn­(II) ions residing at the outer sphere of the cluster in MFU-4l can be exchanged by Cu­(II) ions, resulting in an MOF [Cu3Zn2Cl4(btdd)3] (Cu-MFU-4l ). It is worth noting that the Cu­(II) ions in Cu-MFU-4l exhibit the tetrahedral geometry, while the Cu­(I) ions prefer tetrahedral geometry much more than Cu­(II). Hence, the copper ions can easily retain the coordination geometry after the reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) during the electrocatalysis. In this work, Cu-MFU-4l was employed to investigate the structure and performance for selective conversion of CO2.
elements.clean_text: Previously, Volkmer et al. reported an azolate MOF, namely, [Zn5Cl4(btdd)3] (MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4',5'-i])dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin), constructed by the cationic pentanuclear {Zn5Cl4}6+ clusters and the btdd2- ligands, which has a large pore aperture of 9.13 Å (). There are two types of Zn(II) ions in the {Zn5Cl4}6+ cluster, including four tetrahedral Zn(II) ions, each being coordinated by three N atoms from btdd2- ligands at the base and one Cl- at the apex of the tetrahedron, and one octahedral Zn(II) ion coordinated by six N atoms from six hexadentate btdd2- ligands. Partial Zn(II) ions residing at the outer sphere of the cluster in MFU-4l  can be exchanged by Cu(II) ions, resulting in an MOF [Cu3Zn2Cl4(btdd)3] (Cu-MFU-4l ). It is worth noting that the Cu(II) ions in Cu-MFU-4l  exhibit the tetrahedral geometry, while the Cu(I) ions prefer tetrahedral geometry much more than Cu(II). Hence, the copper ions can easily retain the coordination geometry after the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) during the electrocatalysis. In this work, Cu-MFU-4l  was employed to investigate the structure and performance for selective conversion of CO2.

elements.content: Structures of (a) local coordination environments and metal transformation process and (b) Cu 4 II -MFU-4l (3D channel surface highlighted in yellow).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of (a) local coordination environments and metal transformation process and (b) Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  (3D channel surface highlighted in yellow).

elements.content: Cu-MFU-4l was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn­(II) ions were replaced by Cu­(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4 II -MFU-4l (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4 II -MFU-4l sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: Cu-MFU-4l  was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) ions were replaced by Cu(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).

elements.content: The electrocatalytic CO2RR activity of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l was examined in a 0.5 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution. For comparison, similar measurements for MFU-4l and Cu 4 II -MFU-4l with the same loadings were performed in CO2- and Ar-saturated solutions, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) examinations were carried out (a and S4a). Cu 4 II -MFU-4l exhibits higher current density in the CO2-saturated solution than that in the Ar-saturated solution, indicative of the occurrence of CO2RR. A substantial increase in the current density and a positive shift of the onset potential of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l compared with that of MFU-4l in the CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution was observed, suggesting a better CO2RR performance of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l .
elements.clean_text: The electrocatalytic CO2RR activity of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  was examined in a 0.5 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution. For comparison, similar measurements for MFU-4l  and Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  with the same loadings were performed in CO2- and Ar-saturated solutions, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) examinations were carried out (a and S4a). Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  exhibits higher current density in the CO2-saturated solution than that in the Ar-saturated solution, indicative of the occurrence of CO2RR. A substantial increase in the current density and a positive shift of the onset potential of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  compared with that of MFU-4l  in the CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution was observed, suggesting a better CO2RR performance of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l .

elements.content: CO2RR performances at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1 in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution. (a) LSV curves of MFU-4l and Cu 4 II -MFU-4l . (b) FE and TOF by Cu 4 II -MFU-4l .
elements.clean_text: 2  CO2RR performances at a scan rate of 10 mV s-1 in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution. (a) LSV curves of MFU-4l  and Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l . (b) FE and TOF by Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l .

elements.content: In order to evaluate the CO2RR activity of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l , we examined FE and turnover frequency (TOF) in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution under different potentials (b and S5). The partial current density plots of all products are shown in Figure S4b. Cu 4 II -MFU-4l has a TOF­(CH4) of 0.07 ± 0.01/0.13 ± 0.01 s–1 calculated from three repeated measurements (Figure S4c) and FE­(CH4) of 92%/88% as well as a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm–2 at −1.2/–1.3 V (vs RHE), which represent a high efficiency and selectivity (Table S1). The energy efficiency for yielding CH4 at a potential of −1.2 V (vs RHE) is 81.0% (Figure S6), indicative of a high energy usage. The reduced product given by MFU-4l was only CO with a TOF of 0.012 s–1 and an FE of 17.0% at −1.2 V (vs RHE). It should be noted that, thanks to the coordination saturation of the octahedral zinc ion in the interior of the metal cluster (a), Zn should not be able to act as the active site for CO2RR in the structure of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l , despite the electrochemical performance given by the pyramidal Zn in MFU-4l for yielding CO (Figure S7). In other words, the Cu ions should be the active sites for CO2RR instead of the Zn ions. For comparison, [Cu3(btc)2] (HKUST-1, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Cu2O@Cu-BTC show the FE­(CH4) of 45 and 63.2%, respectively. As far as we know, the performance of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l is the best one among all MOFs for yielding CH4 in CO2RR (Table S1) under neutral conditions. As for other inorganic materials, Barilea and Pan reported a Cu-Nafion electrocatalyst with an FE­(CH4) of 88%/68%, but the current density is only 0.3/0.7 mA cm–2 at −0.89/–0.38 V (vs RHE). Actually, only an FN-CTF-400 compound exhibits a higher FE (FECH4 = 99.3%) than Cu 4 II -MFU-4l but with a current density of only 0.2 mA cm–2 at −0.8 V (vs RHE). The performance of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l is comparable to that of the best catalyst SA-Zn/MNC with an FE­(CH4) of 85% with a current density of 31.8 mA cm–2 at −1.21 V (vs RHE). Due to the involvement of proton and H2O, H2 is usually an ineluctable product. Actually, H2 and CO evolution reaction also occurred in our tests, but the composition of the gas product can be simply tuned by controlling the potential. CO can be regarded as the main product at the low potential. Besides, the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum reveals that no liquid-phase product existed during CO2RR (Figure S8). In order to identify the source of the obtained CH4, we replaced CO2 with 13CO2 and repeated the electrochemical test (Figure S9a). According to gas chromatography–mass spectrometry spectra, 13CH4 and 13CO were observed instead of CH4 and CO, confirming that the carbon in CH4 was originated from CO2. No other hydrocarbons (e.g., 13C2H4 and 13C2H6) or formic acid were observed; thus, no further separation for the product is required in the CO2RR catalyzed by Cu 4 II -MFU-4l .
elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the CO2RR activity of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l , we examined FE and turnover frequency (TOF) in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution under different potentials (b and S5). The partial current density plots of all products are shown in Figure S4b. Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  has a TOF(CH4) of 0.07 ± 0.01/0.13 ± 0.01 s-1 calculated from three repeated measurements (Figure S4c) and FE(CH4) of 92%/88% as well as a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm-2 at -1.2/-1.3 V (vs RHE), which represent a high efficiency and selectivity (Table S1). The energy efficiency for yielding CH4 at a potential of -1.2 V (vs RHE) is 81.0% (Figure S6), indicative of a high energy usage. The reduced product given by MFU-4l  was only CO with a TOF of 0.012 s-1 and an FE of 17.0% at -1.2 V (vs RHE). It should be noted that, thanks to the coordination saturation of the octahedral zinc ion in the interior of the metal cluster (a), Zn should not be able to act as the active site for CO2RR in the structure of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l , despite the electrochemical performance given by the pyramidal Zn in MFU-4l  for yielding CO (Figure S7). In other words, the Cu ions should be the active sites for CO2RR instead of the Zn ions. For comparison, [Cu3(btc)2] (HKUST-1, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Cu2O@Cu-BTC show the FE(CH4) of 45 and 63.2%, respectively. As far as we know, the performance of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  is the best one among all MOFs for yielding CH4 in CO2RR (Table S1) under neutral conditions. As for other inorganic materials, Barilea and Pan reported a Cu-Nafion electrocatalyst with an FE(CH4) of 88%/68%, but the current density is only 0.3/0.7 mA cm-2 at -0.89/-0.38 V (vs RHE). Actually, only an FN-CTF-400 compound exhibits a higher FE (FECH4  = 99.3%) than Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  but with a current density of only 0.2 mA cm-2 at -0.8 V (vs RHE). The performance of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  is comparable to that of the best catalyst SA-Zn/MNC with an FE(CH4) of 85% with a current density of 31.8 mA cm-2 at -1.21 V (vs RHE). Due to the involvement of proton and H2O, H2 is usually an ineluctable product. Actually, H2 and CO evolution reaction also occurred in our tests, but the composition of the gas product can be simply tuned by controlling the potential. CO can be regarded as the main product at the low potential. Besides, the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum reveals that no liquid-phase product existed during CO2RR (Figure S8). In order to identify the source of the obtained CH4, we replaced CO2 with 13CO2 and repeated the electrochemical test (Figure S9a). According to gas chromatography-mass spectrometry spectra, 13CH4 and 13CO were observed instead of CH4 and CO, confirming that the carbon in CH4 was originated from CO2. No other hydrocarbons (e.g., 13C2H4 and 13C2H6) or formic acid were observed; thus, no further separation for the product is required in the CO2RR catalyzed by Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l .

elements.content: Besides the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, durability is also a crucial parameter for electrocatalysts. The durability test of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l was carried out by the continuous electroreduction of CO2 at −1.2 V (Figure S9b). Almost no current attenuation or FE decrease was observed after a 24 h evaluation. Furthermore, PXRD, SEM, and TEM patterns/images of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l showed negligible changes after CO2RR tests for 24 h (Figures S1, S10, and S11). Additionally, as the general methods for electrocatalyst characterization, in situ Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) results ( and S12), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Figure S10a,c) revealed no generation of Cu clusters or Cu–Cu bonds. Therefore, the electrochemical activity of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l should be attributed to the MOF rather than Cu clusters.
elements.clean_text: Besides the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, durability is also a crucial parameter for electrocatalysts. The durability test of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  was carried out by the continuous electroreduction of CO2 at -1.2 V (Figure S9b). Almost no current attenuation or FE decrease was observed after a 24 h evaluation. Furthermore, PXRD, SEM, and TEM patterns/images of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  showed negligible changes after CO2RR tests for 24 h (Figures S1, S10, and S11). Additionally, as the general methods for electrocatalyst characterization, in situ Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) results ( and S12), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Figure S10a,c) revealed no generation of Cu clusters or Cu-Cu bonds. Therefore, the electrochemical activity of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  should be attributed to the MOF rather than Cu clusters.

elements.content: (a) Normalized Cu K-edge XANES spectra and (b) Fourier transform EXAFS spectra of Cu-based samples including Cu 4 II -MFU-4l .
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Normalized Cu K-edge XANES spectra and (b) Fourier transform EXAFS spectra of Cu-based samples including Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l .

elements.content: According to the XPS spectra, the Cl content in Cu 4 II -MFU-4l decreased apparently (the ratio of Cu/Cl = 7.8:1) after the electrocatalysis (Figure S13b,d), which indicates that the Cu­(II) ions were reduced to Cu­(I) and the Cl– ions were eliminated (Figure S14). As a proof, the CV curve of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l in the Ar-saturated solution exhibited a redox peak at a potential of −1.0 V versus RHE (Figure S4a), and the in situ Cu K-edge XANES and EXAFS results demonstrated that the Cu­(II) ions were reduced to Cu­(I) ions to form [Cu 4 Zn­(btdd)3] (Cu 4 I -MFU-4l ) with the trigonal pyramidal Cu­(I)­N3 sites (Figure S12a and Table S2). We proposed that the high durability can be attributed to the tetrahedral coordination geometry of Cu ions in Cu 4 II -MFU-4l . Since a Cu­(I) ion prefers a tetrahedral geometry much more than a Cu­(II) ion, the coordination geometry could be retained after a Cu­(II) ion is reduced to a Cu­(I) ion during the electrocatalysis. In contrast, HKUST-1 decomposed to give Cu clusters after CO2RR. In fact, HKUST-1 shows instability in an aqueous solution, and the preferred square-pyramidal coordination geometry of Cu­(II) in HKUST-1 cannot be retained when the Cu­(II) ions were reduced to Cu­(I) ions in electrocatalysis. Similarly, the Cu/adeninato/carboxylato (Cu-ade) MOF nanosheet with an FE of 12% for CH4 and of 45% for C2H4 had been reported, but it also decomposed into Cu clusters after CO2RR. Actually, the electrocatalytic activities of these Cu-MOFs can be mainly attributed to the Cu clusters generated after the decomposition of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: According to the XPS spectra, the Cl content in Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  decreased apparently (the ratio of Cu/Cl = 7.8:1) after the electrocatalysis (Figure S13b,d), which indicates that the Cu(II) ions were reduced to Cu(I) and the Cl- ions were eliminated (Figure S14). As a proof, the CV curve of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  in the Ar-saturated solution exhibited a redox peak at a potential of -1.0 V versus RHE (Figure S4a), and the in situ Cu K-edge XANES and EXAFS results demonstrated that the Cu(II) ions were reduced to Cu(I) ions to form [Cu 4 Zn(btdd)3] (Cu 4   I  -MFU-4l ) with the trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 sites (Figure S12a and Table S2). We proposed that the high durability can be attributed to the tetrahedral coordination geometry of Cu ions in Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l . Since a Cu(I) ion prefers a tetrahedral geometry much more than a Cu(II) ion, the coordination geometry could be retained after a Cu(II) ion is reduced to a Cu(I) ion during the electrocatalysis. In contrast, HKUST-1 decomposed to give Cu clusters after CO2RR. In fact, HKUST-1 shows instability in an aqueous solution, and the preferred square-pyramidal coordination geometry of Cu(II) in HKUST-1 cannot be retained when the Cu(II) ions were reduced to Cu(I) ions in electrocatalysis. Similarly, the Cu/adeninato/carboxylato (Cu-ade) MOF nanosheet with an FE of 12% for CH4 and of 45% for C2H4 had been reported, but it also decomposed into Cu clusters after CO2RR. Actually, the electrocatalytic activities of these Cu-MOFs can be mainly attributed to the Cu clusters generated after the decomposition of MOFs.

elements.content: Interestingly, the intensity of the peak at 1.5 Å for Cu 4 I -MFU-4l during the CO2RR in the EXAFS result is much higher than that of the electro-reduced form Cu 4 I -MFU-4l in the absence of CO2 (b), implying the increased surrounding coordination atom number of Cu center during the CO2RR. According to our fitting results (Figure S9c,d), the coordination numbers of Cu­(I) ions of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l during CO2RR is 3.9, and the Cu­(I) ion is coordinated by three N atoms and one C atom, respectively, to generate the Cu­(I)­N3C structure. These results strongly proved the existence of the trigonal pyramidal Cu­(I)­N3 sites, which indeed act as the active centers for the CO2RR (Figure S14). To investigate the possible reaction pathway and intermediates of the CO2RR, the in situ attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR–FTIR) measurements were carried out (Figure S15). As a result, we can confirm the existence of *COOH intermediate thanks to the absorption peaks at 1260, 1331, 1400, and 1526 cm–1 (a,b), which present the O–H deformation, C–O bond stretch, and symmetric and asymmetric vibrations, respectively. Especially, as being suggested previously, the *CH3O intermediate evolves from the *CO intermediate. Therefore, the peak at 1166 cm–1 attributable to the *CH3O intermediate is a proof of the existence of the *CO intermediate. Interestingly, the peak at 1670 cm–1 could be ascribed to the CO stretching of *CHO with an obvious red shift, which would be discussed later. It is remarkable that no peak of *CO intermediate was observed in many previous reports, which can be attributed to that the conversion of the *CO intermediate is not the rate-determining step; thus, the *CO intermediate is rapidly consumed and difficult to be detected. Accordingly, after the reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) under electrode potential (Figure S14), the electroreduction of CO2 in the presence of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l might consist of the following steps illustrated in c, which agrees with many previous reports.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the intensity of the peak at 1.5 Å for Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  during the CO2RR in the EXAFS result is much higher than that of the electro-reduced form Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  in the absence of CO2 (b), implying the increased surrounding coordination atom number of Cu center during the CO2RR. According to our fitting results (Figure S9c,d), the coordination numbers of Cu(I) ions of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  during CO2RR is 3.9, and the Cu(I) ion is coordinated by three N atoms and one C atom, respectively, to generate the Cu(I)N3C structure. These results strongly proved the existence of the trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 sites, which indeed act as the active centers for the CO2RR (Figure S14). To investigate the possible reaction pathway and intermediates of the CO2RR, the in situ attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) measurements were carried out (Figure S15). As a result, we can confirm the existence of *COOH intermediate thanks to the absorption peaks at 1260, 1331, 1400, and 1526 cm-1 (a,b), which present the O-H deformation, C-O bond stretch, and symmetric and asymmetric vibrations, respectively. Especially, as being suggested previously, the *CH3O intermediate evolves from the *CO intermediate. Therefore, the peak at 1166 cm-1 attributable to the *CH3O intermediate is a proof of the existence of the *CO intermediate. Interestingly, the peak at 1670 cm-1 could be ascribed to the CO stretching of *CHO with an obvious red shift, which would be discussed later. It is remarkable that no peak of *CO intermediate was observed in many previous reports, which can be attributed to that the conversion of the *CO intermediate is not the rate-determining step; thus, the *CO intermediate is rapidly consumed and difficult to be detected. Accordingly, after the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) under electrode potential (Figure S14), the electroreduction of CO2 in the presence of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  might consist of the following steps illustrated in c, which agrees with many previous reports.

elements.content: (a,b) In situ ATR–FTIR spectra of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l collected at −1.2 V vs RHE in CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 electrolyte. (c) Possible pathway for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CH4 on Cu 4 I -MFU-4l after the reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) during the electrocatalysis. (d) Illustration of the energy barriers of the electroreduction pathway.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a,b) In situ ATR-FTIR spectra of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  collected at -1.2 V vs RHE in CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 electrolyte. (c) Possible pathway for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CH4 on Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  after the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) during the electrocatalysis. (d) Illustration of the energy barriers of the electroreduction pathway.

elements.content: Based on the result of the in situ infrared spectroscopy experiment, we further carried out density functional theory (DFT) calculations to understand the catalytic mechanism. First, we studied the structure and energy of *COOH and *H2O intermediates. According to our DFT calculation results, the Cu–C distance in *COOH is 1.929 Å with the binding energy and adsorption free energies of −1.72 and −1.21 eV, respectively. By comparison, the binding energy and the adsorption free energy of H2O on Cu­(I)­N3 are −0.50 and −0.04 eV, respectively (d), indicative of the difficulty of the adsorption of H2O. Further DFT analyses revealed that the Cu–O distance in *H2O is 2.195 Å ( and S16), which is much longer than the reported average value (∼1.95 Å). Through careful structural analysis, we found that the shortest distance between the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms of the ligand and those of the H2O molecule is just 2.803 Å, which will be further shortened to 2.629 Å when the Cu–O distance in *H2O is reduced from 2.195 Å to the average value of 1.950 Å. This phenomenon indicates that the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms may expel the H2O molecule, thus suppressing the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).
elements.clean_text: Based on the result of the in situ infrared spectroscopy experiment, we further carried out density functional theory (DFT) calculations to understand the catalytic mechanism. First, we studied the structure and energy of *COOH and *H2O intermediates. According to our DFT calculation results, the Cu-C distance in *COOH is 1.929 Å with the binding energy and adsorption free energies of -1.72 and -1.21 eV, respectively. By comparison, the binding energy and the adsorption free energy of H2O on Cu(I)N3 are -0.50 and -0.04 eV, respectively (d), indicative of the difficulty of the adsorption of H2O. Further DFT analyses revealed that the Cu-O distance in *H2O is 2.195 Å ( and S16), which is much longer than the reported average value (~1.95 Å). Through careful structural analysis, we found that the shortest distance between the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms of the ligand and those of the H2O molecule is just 2.803 Å, which will be further shortened to 2.629 Å when the Cu-O distance in *H2O is reduced from 2.195 Å to the average value of 1.950 Å. This phenomenon indicates that the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms may expel the H2O molecule, thus suppressing the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).

elements.content: We subsequently studied the mechanism of CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Cu­(I)­N3 active site of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l . The structures for the important intermediates (e.g., CO, CHO, CH2O, CH3O, etc.) adsorbed on the Cu­(I)­N3 active sites were optimized by the DFT calculations. According to the calculation results (d), the hydrogenation energy barrier of CO (−0.11 eV) is much lower than its desorption energy barrier (−0.84 eV), indicating that the hydrogenation of CO to CHO is thermodynamically favorable. Specifically, the adsorption energy of the CO intermediate is −0.84 eV with a Cu–C distance of 1.801 Å (Figure S16d), indicating that the Cu­(I)­N3 active site has very high affinity to CO. This phenomenon might be ascribed to the fact that there is a σ–π back bonding formed between Cu­(I) and CO. Such high binding energy for CO is beneficial for hydrogenation of *CO intermediate.
elements.clean_text: We subsequently studied the mechanism of CO2 reduction to CH4 on the Cu(I)N3 active site of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l . The structures for the important intermediates (e.g., CO, CHO, CH2O, CH3O, etc.) adsorbed on the Cu(I)N3 active sites were optimized by the DFT calculations. According to the calculation results (d), the hydrogenation energy barrier of CO (-0.11 eV) is much lower than its desorption energy barrier (-0.84 eV), indicating that the hydrogenation of CO to CHO is thermodynamically favorable. Specifically, the adsorption energy of the CO intermediate is -0.84 eV with a Cu-C distance of 1.801 Å (Figure S16d), indicating that the Cu(I)N3 active site has very high affinity to CO. This phenomenon might be ascribed to the fact that there is a σ-π back bonding formed between Cu(I) and CO. Such high binding energy for CO is beneficial for hydrogenation of *CO intermediate.

elements.content: For the *CHO intermediate, the adsorption energy is −1.53 eV and the Cu–C distance is 1.906 Å, indicating that the interaction between the Cu­(I)­N3 active site and CHO is also very strong. After careful structure analysis, we found that there is a strong nonclassical C–H···O hydrogen bond (C···O = 3.446 Å, H···O = 2.415 Å, and ∠C–H···O = 150.1°) with an energy of 14.3 kJ mol–1 between CHO and the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms from the ligand (Figure S16c). It should be noted that the nonclassical hydrogen bond can be demonstrated by the red shift of the absorption peak of *CHO at 1670 cm–1 in the in situ ATR–FTIR spectra, and the absorption peak is widened by the hydrogen bond. Actually, a similar red shift can also be observed in the peak at 1526 cm–1 of *COOH (∼1565 cm–1 generally). This result indicates that, in addition to the strong coordination interaction, the hydrogen bonding interaction also plays an important role in stabilizing the key intermediate of CHO. As a result, the hydrogenation of *CO to *CHO intermediate is dominant rather than the desorption of CO species. In fact, the energy barriers of hydrogenation of other intermediates are all lower than that of desorption (d), which finally results in CH4 as the main product rather than formic acid, formaldehyde, or methanol. It should be noted that the energy barrier of the reaction of *OH to the original * site (1.33 eV) is much higher than that of the reaction of *OH to *COOH (0.12 eV); thus, we proposed the mechanism that the *OH intermediate can be directly transferred to *COOH rather than to the original * site, and another CO2RR will be performed subsequently (c). The structures of all intermediates are depicted in Figure S17. In short, the strong coordination ability of the Cu­(I)­N3 active site as well as the synergistic effect of the nonclassical hydrogen bonding interaction play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of CO2RR and suppressing the HER. As a result, Cu 4 I -MFU-4l exhibits high performance for electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.
elements.clean_text: For the *CHO intermediate, the adsorption energy is -1.53 eV and the Cu-C distance is 1.906 Å, indicating that the interaction between the Cu(I)N3 active site and CHO is also very strong. After careful structure analysis, we found that there is a strong nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (C⋅⋅⋅O = 3.446 Å, H⋅⋅⋅O = 2.415 Å, and ∠C-H⋅⋅⋅O = 150.1°) with an energy of 14.3 kJ mol-1 between CHO and the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms from the ligand (Figure S16c). It should be noted that the nonclassical hydrogen bond can be demonstrated by the red shift of the absorption peak of *CHO at 1670 cm-1 in the in situ ATR-FTIR spectra, and the absorption peak is widened by the hydrogen bond. Actually, a similar red shift can also be observed in the peak at 1526 cm-1 of *COOH (~1565 cm-1 generally). This result indicates that, in addition to the strong coordination interaction, the hydrogen bonding interaction also plays an important role in stabilizing the key intermediate of CHO. As a result, the hydrogenation of *CO to *CHO intermediate is dominant rather than the desorption of CO species. In fact, the energy barriers of hydrogenation of other intermediates are all lower than that of desorption (d), which finally results in CH4 as the main product rather than formic acid, formaldehyde, or methanol. It should be noted that the energy barrier of the reaction of *OH to the original * site (1.33 eV) is much higher than that of the reaction of *OH to *COOH (0.12 eV); thus, we proposed the mechanism that the *OH intermediate can be directly transferred to *COOH rather than to the original * site, and another CO2RR will be performed subsequently (c). The structures of all intermediates are depicted in Figure S17. In short, the strong coordination ability of the Cu(I)N3 active site as well as the synergistic effect of the nonclassical hydrogen bonding interaction play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of CO2RR and suppressing the HER. As a result, Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  exhibits high performance for electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.

elements.content: To further confirm the important role of the trigonal pyramidal Cu­(I)­N3 sites in the CO2RR, we performed some supplementary experiments to explore the interaction between Cu­(I)­N3 and CO. Since the Cu­(I) ions of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l are easy to be oxidized when exposed to air, it is very difficult to characterize the structure of the sample obtained from electroreduction method. Fortunately, Cu 4 I -MFU-4l was successfully obtained by ion-exchange and heating-induced reduction methods. The Rietveld refinement of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l proved that the transition from Cu­(II)­N3Cl to Cu­(I)­N3 does not destroy the crystal structure (Figure S18a and Table S3). The electrochemical measurement showed that Cu 4 I -MFU-4l has a similar electrocatalytic performance with that of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l (Figure S19), again demonstrating that the trigonal pyramid Cu­(I)­N3 sites indeed act as the active centers for CO2RR. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectrum shows a sharp peak at 2056.9 cm–1, indicating the successful chemical adsorption of CO on Cu 4 I -MFU-4l (Figure S20). To further visualize the host–guest interactions, the Rietveld refinement of Cu 4 I -MFU-4l loaded with a CO gas molecule was performed. As shown in Figure S18b and Table S3, the CO molecule was coordinated with the Cu­(I) ion of the Cu­(I)­N3 site in Cu 4 I -MFU-4l , (Cu­(I)···CO = 1.83(2) Å), which is consistent with the DFT result. Such a strong Cu–CO binding interaction prevents desorption of CO species and promotes formation of the *CHO intermediate. On the one hand, the stable Cu–C bond is not beneficial to desorption of CO; on the other hand, as mentioned earlier, the nonclassical hydrogen bond is conducive to stabilizing the *CHO intermediate. The synergistic effect of these two steps are both beneficial for hydrogenation of the *CO intermediate and inhibit desorption of CO. Such a mechanism of the selective reduction of CO2 has not been reported.
elements.clean_text: To further confirm the important role of the trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 sites in the CO2RR, we performed some supplementary experiments to explore the interaction between Cu(I)N3 and CO. Since the Cu(I) ions of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  are easy to be oxidized when exposed to air, it is very difficult to characterize the structure of the sample obtained from electroreduction method. Fortunately, Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  was successfully obtained by ion-exchange and heating-induced reduction methods. The Rietveld refinement of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  proved that the transition from Cu(II)N3Cl to Cu(I)N3 does not destroy the crystal structure (Figure S18a and Table S3). The electrochemical measurement showed that Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  has a similar electrocatalytic performance with that of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  (Figure S19), again demonstrating that the trigonal pyramid Cu(I)N3 sites indeed act as the active centers for CO2RR. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectrum shows a sharp peak at 2056.9 cm-1, indicating the successful chemical adsorption of CO on Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  (Figure S20). To further visualize the host-guest interactions, the Rietveld refinement of Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l  loaded with a CO gas molecule was performed. As shown in Figure S18b and Table S3, the CO molecule was coordinated with the Cu(I) ion of the Cu(I)N3 site in Cu  4   I  -MFU-4l , (Cu(I)⋅⋅⋅CO = 1.83(2) Å), which is consistent with the DFT result. Such a strong Cu-CO binding interaction prevents desorption of CO species and promotes formation of the *CHO intermediate. On the one hand, the stable Cu-C bond is not beneficial to desorption of CO; on the other hand, as mentioned earlier, the nonclassical hydrogen bond is conducive to stabilizing the *CHO intermediate. The synergistic effect of these two steps are both beneficial for hydrogenation of the *CO intermediate and inhibit desorption of CO. Such a mechanism of the selective reduction of CO2 has not been reported.

elements.content: In summary, we achieved an excellent electrocatalytic performance for CO2RR into CH4 by using the Cu–triazole-based MOF as the catalyst. The impressive electrocatalytic activity and selectivity can be attributed to the strong interaction between Cu­(I) and key intermediates, as well as the synergistic effect of organic ligands through the hydrogen bond interaction. Additionally, the tetrahedral coordination geometry of the Cu site endows the MOF with high durability. The results provide a new clue for designing high-performance MOFs for the electrocatalytic generation of value-added hydrocarbons.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we achieved an excellent electrocatalytic performance for CO2RR into CH4 by using the Cu-triazole-based MOF as the catalyst. The impressive electrocatalytic activity and selectivity can be attributed to the strong interaction between Cu(I) and key intermediates, as well as the synergistic effect of organic ligands through the hydrogen bond interaction. Additionally, the tetrahedral coordination geometry of the Cu site endows the MOF with high durability. The results provide a new clue for designing high-performance MOFs for the electrocatalytic generation of value-added hydrocarbons.

cln_elements.content: Cu-MFU-4l was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn­(II) ions were replaced by Cu­(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4 II -MFU-4l (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4 II -MFU-4l sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).
cln_elements.clean_text: Cu-MFU-4l  was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) ions were replaced by Cu(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).

cln_elements.content:
High-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction reaction are extremely desirable to produce valuable hydrocarbon productions, as well as addressing the current environmental challenges. In this work, we introduce a Cu-based metal–organic framework as a catalyst for the efficient and selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 in neutral aqueous electrolytes. Detailed examination of [Cu 4 ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Cu 4 -MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis­(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4′,5′-i])­dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin) revealed the highest activity for yielding methane with a Faradaic efficiency of 92%/88% and a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm–2 at a potential of −1.2/–1.3 V (vs RHE). In situ X-ray absorption and infrared spectroscopy spectra, as well as density functional theory calculations, revealed that the in situ generated trigonal pyramidal Cu­(I)­N3 acts as the electrochemical active site and that the strong coordination ability of the Cu­(I)­N3 site and the synergistic effect of adjacent aromatic hydrogen atoms, via hydrogen-bonding interactions, play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of carbon dioxide reduction and inhibiting the hydrogen evolution reaction, thus showing a high performance of electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.

In order to evaluate the CO2RR activity of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l , we examined FE and turnover frequency (TOF) in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution under different potentials (b and S5). The partial current density plots of all products are shown in Figure S4b. Cu 4 II -MFU-4l has a TOF­(CH4) of 0.07 ± 0.01/0.13 ± 0.01 s–1 calculated from three repeated measurements (Figure S4c) and FE­(CH4) of 92%/88% as well as a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm–2 at −1.2/–1.3 V (vs RHE), which represent a high efficiency and selectivity (Table S1). The energy efficiency for yielding CH4 at a potential of −1.2 V (vs RHE) is 81.0% (Figure S6), indicative of a high energy usage. The reduced product given by MFU-4l was only CO with a TOF of 0.012 s–1 and an FE of 17.0% at −1.2 V (vs RHE). It should be noted that, thanks to the coordination saturation of the octahedral zinc ion in the interior of the metal cluster (a), Zn should not be able to act as the active site for CO2RR in the structure of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l , despite the electrochemical performance given by the pyramidal Zn in MFU-4l for yielding CO (Figure S7). In other words, the Cu ions should be the active sites for CO2RR instead of the Zn ions. For comparison, [Cu3(btc)2] (HKUST-1, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Cu2O@Cu-BTC show the FE­(CH4) of 45 and 63.2%, respectively. As far as we know, the performance of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l is the best one among all MOFs for yielding CH4 in CO2RR (Table S1) under neutral conditions. As for other inorganic materials, Barilea and Pan reported a Cu-Nafion electrocatalyst with an FE­(CH4) of 88%/68%, but the current density is only 0.3/0.7 mA cm–2 at −0.89/–0.38 V (vs RHE). Actually, only an FN-CTF-400 compound exhibits a higher FE (FECH4 = 99.3%) than Cu 4 II -MFU-4l but with a current density of only 0.2 mA cm–2 at −0.8 V (vs RHE). The performance of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l is comparable to that of the best catalyst SA-Zn/MNC with an FE­(CH4) of 85% with a current density of 31.8 mA cm–2 at −1.21 V (vs RHE). Due to the involvement of proton and H2O, H2 is usually an ineluctable product. Actually, H2 and CO evolution reaction also occurred in our tests, but the composition of the gas product can be simply tuned by controlling the potential. CO can be regarded as the main product at the low potential. Besides, the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum reveals that no liquid-phase product existed during CO2RR (Figure S8). In order to identify the source of the obtained CH4, we replaced CO2 with 13CO2 and repeated the electrochemical test (Figure S9a). According to gas chromatography–mass spectrometry spectra, 13CH4 and 13CO were observed instead of CH4 and CO, confirming that the carbon in CH4 was originated from CO2. No other hydrocarbons (e.g., 13C2H4 and 13C2H6) or formic acid were observed; thus, no further separation for the product is required in the CO2RR catalyzed by Cu 4 II -MFU-4l .

Besides the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, durability is also a crucial parameter for electrocatalysts. The durability test of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l was carried out by the continuous electroreduction of CO2 at −1.2 V (Figure S9b). Almost no current attenuation or FE decrease was observed after a 24 h evaluation. Furthermore, PXRD, SEM, and TEM patterns/images of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l showed negligible changes after CO2RR tests for 24 h (Figures S1, S10, and S11). Additionally, as the general methods for electrocatalyst characterization, in situ Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) results ( and S12), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Figure S10a,c) revealed no generation of Cu clusters or Cu–Cu bonds. Therefore, the electrochemical activity of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l should be attributed to the MOF rather than Cu clusters.
cln_elements.clean_text:
High-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction reaction are extremely desirable to produce valuable hydrocarbon productions, as well as addressing the current environmental challenges. In this work, we introduce a Cu-based metal-organic framework as a catalyst for the efficient and selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 in neutral aqueous electrolytes. Detailed examination of [Cu 4 ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Cu  4  -MFU-4l , H2btdd = bis(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b],[4',5'-i])dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin) revealed the highest activity for yielding methane with a Faradaic efficiency of 92%/88% and a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm-2 at a potential of -1.2/-1.3 V (vs RHE). In situ X-ray absorption and infrared spectroscopy spectra, as well as density functional theory calculations, revealed that the in situ generated trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 acts as the electrochemical active site and that the strong coordination ability of the Cu(I)N3 site and the synergistic effect of adjacent aromatic hydrogen atoms, via hydrogen-bonding interactions, play an important role in stabilizing the key intermediates of carbon dioxide reduction and inhibiting the hydrogen evolution reaction, thus showing a high performance of electroreduction of CO2 to CH4.

In order to evaluate the CO2RR activity of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l , we examined FE and turnover frequency (TOF) in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M NaHCO3 solution under different potentials (b and S5). The partial current density plots of all products are shown in Figure S4b. Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  has a TOF(CH4) of 0.07 ± 0.01/0.13 ± 0.01 s-1 calculated from three repeated measurements (Figure S4c) and FE(CH4) of 92%/88% as well as a partial current density of 9.8/18.3 mA cm-2 at -1.2/-1.3 V (vs RHE), which represent a high efficiency and selectivity (Table S1). The energy efficiency for yielding CH4 at a potential of -1.2 V (vs RHE) is 81.0% (Figure S6), indicative of a high energy usage. The reduced product given by MFU-4l  was only CO with a TOF of 0.012 s-1 and an FE of 17.0% at -1.2 V (vs RHE). It should be noted that, thanks to the coordination saturation of the octahedral zinc ion in the interior of the metal cluster (a), Zn should not be able to act as the active site for CO2RR in the structure of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l , despite the electrochemical performance given by the pyramidal Zn in MFU-4l  for yielding CO (Figure S7). In other words, the Cu ions should be the active sites for CO2RR instead of the Zn ions. For comparison, [Cu3(btc)2] (HKUST-1, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Cu2O@Cu-BTC show the FE(CH4) of 45 and 63.2%, respectively. As far as we know, the performance of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  is the best one among all MOFs for yielding CH4 in CO2RR (Table S1) under neutral conditions. As for other inorganic materials, Barilea and Pan reported a Cu-Nafion electrocatalyst with an FE(CH4) of 88%/68%, but the current density is only 0.3/0.7 mA cm-2 at -0.89/-0.38 V (vs RHE). Actually, only an FN-CTF-400 compound exhibits a higher FE (FECH4  = 99.3%) than Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  but with a current density of only 0.2 mA cm-2 at -0.8 V (vs RHE). The performance of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  is comparable to that of the best catalyst SA-Zn/MNC with an FE(CH4) of 85% with a current density of 31.8 mA cm-2 at -1.21 V (vs RHE). Due to the involvement of proton and H2O, H2 is usually an ineluctable product. Actually, H2 and CO evolution reaction also occurred in our tests, but the composition of the gas product can be simply tuned by controlling the potential. CO can be regarded as the main product at the low potential. Besides, the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum reveals that no liquid-phase product existed during CO2RR (Figure S8). In order to identify the source of the obtained CH4, we replaced CO2 with 13CO2 and repeated the electrochemical test (Figure S9a). According to gas chromatography-mass spectrometry spectra, 13CH4 and 13CO were observed instead of CH4 and CO, confirming that the carbon in CH4 was originated from CO2. No other hydrocarbons (e.g., 13C2H4 and 13C2H6) or formic acid were observed; thus, no further separation for the product is required in the CO2RR catalyzed by Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l .

Besides the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, durability is also a crucial parameter for electrocatalysts. The durability test of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  was carried out by the continuous electroreduction of CO2 at -1.2 V (Figure S9b). Almost no current attenuation or FE decrease was observed after a 24 h evaluation. Furthermore, PXRD, SEM, and TEM patterns/images of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  showed negligible changes after CO2RR tests for 24 h (Figures S1, S10, and S11). Additionally, as the general methods for electrocatalyst characterization, in situ Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) results ( and S12), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Figure S10a,c) revealed no generation of Cu clusters or Cu-Cu bonds. Therefore, the electrochemical activity of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  should be attributed to the MOF rather than Cu clusters.

(d) Illustration of the energy barriers of the electroreduction pathway.

metadata.title:
Highly Efficient Electroconversion of CO2 into CH4 by a Metal–Organic Framework with Trigonal
Pyramidal Cu(I)N3 Active Sites
